answers.body_markdown:
It seems you don't even have a "Suit" on your cards, so how will you detect a Flush?

Here is an example for a nice "Deck Of Cards" and detecting a Flush.
Combine that with the `collections.Counter` I suggested in your other question, 
and you will have most of the combinations.

I'd suggest to read up on objects and classes
(e.g. http://introtopython.org/classes.html)

And I'll leave it to you to create a `class Hand`, which takes 5 cards in `__init__` and has methods like `is_flush()`...

```python
from collections import namedtuple
from random import shuffle

Card = namedtuple("Card", "suit, rank")

class Deck:
    suits = '♦♥♠♣'
    ranks = '23456789JQKA'

    def __init__(self):
        self.cards = [Card(suit, rank) for suit in self.suits for rank in self.ranks]
        shuffle(self.cards)

    def deal(self, amount):
        return tuple(self.cards.pop() for _ in range(amount))



flush = False
while not flush:
    deck = Deck()

    while len(deck.cards) > 5:
        hand = deck.deal(5)
        # (Card(suit='♣', rank='7'), Card(suit='♠', rank='2'), Card(suit='♥', rank='4'), Card(suit='♥', rank='K'), Card(suit='♣', rank='3'))

        if len(set(card.suit for card in hand)) > 1:
            print(f"No Flush: {hand}")
            continue

        print(f"Yay, it's a Flush: {hand}")
        flush = True
        break

# No Flush: (Card(suit='♠', rank='K'), Card(suit='♣', rank='6'), Card(suit='♦', rank='6'), Card(suit='♣', rank='4'), Card(suit='♠', rank='Q'))
# No Flush: (Card(suit='♠', rank='J'), Card(suit='♥', rank='9'), Card(suit='♥', rank='3'), Card(suit='♣', rank='2'), Card(suit='♠', rank='6'))
# No Flush: (Card(suit='♣', rank='7'), Card(suit='♥', rank='5'), Card(suit='♦', rank='5'), Card(suit='♦', rank='Q'), Card(suit='♦', rank='K'))
# Yay, it's a Flush: (Card(suit='♣', rank='3'), Card(suit='♣', rank='A'), Card(suit='♣', rank='J'), Card(suit='♣', rank='9'), Card(suit='♣', rank='5'))
```

answers.body_markdown:
It sounds like you want the book object to stick around after you delete the author so you can then assign it to another author.  If that is the case, you might want to consider using a has and belongs to many relationship: https://guides.rubyonrails.org/association_basics.html#the-has-and-belongs-to-many-association.  So you would have 3 tables: `authors`, `books` and `authors_books`. `author_books` would only have 2 columns: `author_id` and `book_id`.

Another option would be to change `Author` like so:

```
  class Author < ApplicationRecord
    has_many :books, dependent: :nullify
  end
```

Now when an author is deleted, the books are not deleted, instead `author_id` is set to null in the books table for all the books that previously belonged to a particular author: https://guides.rubyonrails.org/association_basics.html#dependent
answers.title: Rails update author_id in books table after deleting and creating a new author record

There are many ways in angular to make data transfer between two components. As you have requested for the changes to be detected by a list of subscribers, [https://stackoverflow.com/a/58092434/6835898][1] is the perfect answer.
Other ways of data transfer are based on the relationship between two components, as in parent-child, child-parent, siblings. For smaller projects, Observables sounds like a good idea but as projects go bigger, you will have to make a dictionary for all the different Observables you will be using all over the project. And so, EventEmitters and Inputs are the best ones to use for data transfers in big projects.

answers.body_markdown:
I would not use = to compare times like that. The chances you will hit the exact millisecond needed for the times to be considered equal is very very unlikely 

Instead make your test using >

    If(DateTime.Now > mydatetimepicker.Value)
      a1.BackColor = Color.LightBlue
    End If

Make your timer tick at 1000 millisecond interval. It means that within a second of the world time rolling past the time in the picker, the screen will change. If you need more accuracy, make the timer tick more often. It is better to make the timer tick not very often though, so don't set the interval to 1ms- set it to as long as possible so that your requirement is still met. Like if you're making a clock for your kid to know he can only get out of bed when the screen goes blue, that would be fine at 10 seconds interval or something. If you're timing an industrial process that needs to show a change within half a second make the interval half of that requirement , so 250ms

items.body_markdown:
We've got a few in-house packages - both Nuget and NPM - that we are using across a number of in-house applications. All of those packages are treated as sort of beta/early access - there are no formal requirements/etc and changes are done on a case by case basis.

What we are struggling with is versioning. As far as I understand, at least for NPM packages, the version numbers should be major.minor.patch or breaking-changes.new-features.bug-fixes.

What we are finding is that there is a tendency to make breaking changes to the packages and simply increment the patch versin, which leads to confusion. One argument is that we are supposed to increment the major version every time we have a breaking change. The other argument is that as we are pre-v1.0, breaking changes are expected, so patch/minor version increments are fine.

The final complication is the fact that some of these packages depend on other packages, let's say Angular. As we update to later Angular versions, we find ourselves struggling with versioning even more as there is a desire to align with Angular version increments, yet support the ability to increment major versions for breaking changes. We are currently discussing moving to angular-version.breaking-changes.non-breaking-changes way of versioning of our packages.

Curious to hear some thoughts on semantic versioning from anyone who thinks they've got it right. How do you do it? When do you go from `-beta` to `1.0`? Do you use major/minor/patch versioning as intended?
items.title: NPM semantic versioning for alpha/beta packages

answers.body_markdown:
I suppose you misunderstood the `Global admin` and `Owner`. The `Global admin` is an [`Administrator role`][1] in Azure AD, and the `Owner` is an [`RBAC role`][2] in the subscription. They are different things.

When you use the azure cli like below to create the role assignment, it adds the service principal `joytestsp` as an `Owner` to the storage account. The service principal which you login needs to call the AAD Graph to get the object first and then call the azure mangement rest api to add it to the storage account.

    az role assignment create --assignee 'joytestsp' --role 'Owner' --scope '/subscriptions/xxxxxx/resourceGroups/xxx/providers/Microsoft.Storage/storageAccounts/joyfunction'

So to fix the issue, you could navigate to the `Azure Active Directory` in the portal -> `Roles and administrators` -> click the `Global administrator` -> `Add assignments`-> add your service principal which used to login as a `Global administrator`. Then it should work.


----------

**Besides**, if you don't want to give it the `Global administrator` to the service principal, you can also specify the `object id` of the service principal/user in the command, then it will also work.

    az role assignment create --assignee 'b4d3c922-xxxxxxx-3ab785333011' --role 'Owner' --scope '/subscriptions/xxxxxx/resourceGroups/xxx/providers/Microsoft.Storage/storageAccounts/joyfunction'


  [1]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/users-groups-roles/directory-assign-admin-roles
  [2]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/role-based-access-control/built-in-roles

Yes. You can evaluate expressions while debugging. You can use either `call <expr>` or `print <expr>`, but the expression must be known at the time of breakpoint.

In your example, you could do:
```
gdb ./test
(gdb) b main
...
(gdb) r
...
(gdb) call func(11)
11
```

More info about call/print: https://sourceware.org/gdb/onlinedocs/gdb/Calling.html

answers.title: Is there any operation on two numpy array to discard zero values?

answers.body_markdown:
Given that you want to keep `x2` but make it zero in the case `x1` is zero, just multiply `x2` by the boolean of `x1`.

    >>> x2 * x1.astype(bool)
    array([[0, 3, 0, 6, 0]])

Note that if x2 is zero, the result is zero as expected.

answers.body_markdown:
The difference between Sequential and functional keras API:

> The sequential API allows you to create models layer-by-layer for most
> problems. It is limited in that it does not allow you to create models
> that share layers or have multiple inputs or outputs.

> the functional API allows you to create models that have a lot more
> flexibility as you can easily define models where layers connect to
> more than just the previous and next layers. In fact, you can connect
> layers to (literally) any other layer. As a result, creating complex
> networks such as siamese networks and residual networks become
> possible.


To answer your question:

No these APIs are not the same and the number of layers is normal that are the same number.
Which one to use? It depends on the use you want to make of this network. What are you doing the training for? What do you want the output to be?


I recommend this link to make the most of the concept.

[Sequential Models & Functional Models ][1]


  [1]: https://jovianlin.io/keras-models-sequential-vs-functional/



I hope I helped you understand better.
answers.title: Keras' Sequential vs Functional API for Multi-Task Learning Neural Network

answers.body_markdown:
Both models are (in theory) equivalent, as the two output nodes do not have any interaction between them.

It is just that the required outputs have a different shape 

    [(batch_size,2)]
vs

    [(batch_size,),(batch_size,)]

and thus, the loss will be different.

The total loss is averaged for the sequential model in this example, whereas it is summed up for the functional model with two outputs (at least with a default loss such as MSE).

Of course, you can also adapt the functional model to be exactly equivalent to the sequential model:

    out1 = Dense(2)(lay2)
    #out2 = Dense(1)(lay2)
    func_model = Model(inputs=input1, outputs=out1)

Maybe you will also need some activations after the Dense layers.
answers.title: Keras' Sequential vs Functional API for Multi-Task Learning Neural Network

Underneath I provide the code I used to build a network using both approaches to build a network with two outputs:

**Sequential**  

    seq_model = Sequential()
    seq_model.add(LSTM(32, input_shape=(10,2)))
    seq_model.add(Dense(8))
    seq_model.add(Dense(2))
    seq_model.summary()

**Functional**

    input1 = Input(shape=(10,2))
    lay1 = LSTM(32, input_shape=(10,2))(input1)
    lay2 = Dense(8)(lay1)
    out1 = Dense(1)(lay2)
    out2 = Dense(1)(lay2)
    func_model = Model(inputs=input1, outputs=[out1, out2])

This code is poorly-structured and needs to be re-written for testability. As it is currently structured, this code is not testable at all. Problems:

answers.body_markdown:
You got the errors because you are attempting to convert RDD into Vectors forcibly.

You can achieve what you need without doing the conversion by doing the following steps :

 1. Join both your RDDs into one RDD. Note that I am assuming you do not have a unique index in both RDDs for joining.
```
# Adding index to both RDDs by row.
rdd1 = normalizedtfidf.zipWithIndex().map(lambda arg : (arg[1], arg[0]))
rdd2 = keywordTF.zipWithIndex().map(lambda arg : (arg[1], arg[0]))

# Join both RDDs.
rdd_joined = rdd1.join(rdd2)
```

 2. `map` RDD with a function to calculate cosine distance.
```
def cosine_dist(row):
    x = row[1][0]
    y = row[1][1]
    return (1 - x.dot(y)/(x.norm(2)*y.norm(2)))

res = rdd_joined.map(cosine_dist)
```

You can then use your results or run `collect` to see them.

According to a response to a [similar issue on the stable_baseline repository][1], it seems that keras does not support shared weights between multiple agents. Therefore, when training an actor-critic network with multiple instances, every environment has its own network which leads to completely different results. The fix is to only use tensorflow layers directly which support reuse of the same weights.


  [1]: https://github.com/hill-a/stable-baselines/issues/220#issuecomment-470083299

>> **ExcludeMatchedPattern**:
Used to indicate that the pattern determines which webhook events do not trigger a build. If true, then a webhook event that does not match the pattern triggers a build. If false, then a webhook event that matches the pattern triggers a build.
